title.value: Towards Machines that Trust: AI Agents Learn to Trust in the Trust Game
title.justification: Found in the provided metadata and document title.
title.quote: Towards Machines that Trust: AI Agents Learn to Trust in the Trust Game

extractions.description: This paper presents a theoretical analysis of the trust game, a canonical task for studying trust in behavioral and brain sciences, along with reinforcement learning (RL) simulations to investigate how AI agents can learn to trust under various parameterizations of the task.

type.justification: The paper focuses on a theoretical analysis of the trust game and supports this with simulation results.
type.quote: As we show, our simulation results support our theoretical analysis.

name.justification: The paper leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to investigate learning trust.
name.quote: Additionally, leveraging reinforcement learning (RL) to train our AI agents, we systematically investigate learning trust under various parameterizations of this task.

name.justification: The trust game is studied in the context of behavioral and brain sciences.
name.quote: the canonical task for studying trust in behavioral and brain sciences (e.g., Camerer & Weigelt, 1988; Fehr, 2009; Tzieropoulos, 2013; Johnson & Mislin, 2011; Mitkidis et al., 2017; Al√≥s-Ferrer & Farolfi, 2019).

name.justification: The RL Trustor model employs Thompson Sampling for decision-making.
name.quote: To train RL Trustor, we adopt Thompson Sampling (Thompson, 1933), a well-established method that enjoys near-optimality guarantees (Agrawal & Goyal, 2012, 2013).

is_contributed.justification: Thompson Sampling is used as a method in the research but is not a contribution of the paper itself.
is_contributed.quote: To train RL Trustor, we adopt Thompson Sampling (Thompson, 1933)

is_executed.justification: Thompson Sampling was employed in the simulations run by the authors.
is_executed.quote: In Figure 1, we simulate 10 RL Trustors and report the mean frequency of a fraction being transferred to TG Trustee over the past trials, for a total of N = 20, 000 trials.

is_compared.justification: No comparison with other models was indicated.
is_compared.quote: Our theoretical analysis, corroborated by the simulations results presented, provides a mathematical basis for the emergence of trust in the trust game.
